I saw the Sun rise glorious in front of my window but had no time, but to dress and pack my trunk for departure. At a quarter past six we breakfasted—then took leave of Mrs Grinnell and the young Ladies— Mr Grinnell took us in his carriage to the railroad depot, and accompanied us to Boston— The train started from the depot precisely at 7. and we landed at the depot at the bottom of the common in Boston at ten— In the cars I met a young man named Elliot, son of Mr and Mrs Elliot of Washington, and Mr Durfee (Nathan) a representative in the Legislature of the Commonwealth from Fall-river in 1841— At the depot in Boston I parted from Mr Brooks and Mr Grinnell; stop’d at the shop of Mr Mitchell, Seal engraver and took the Seal ordered for Captain Buchanan— I found my Son at his office, and Mr Spooner came in while I was there— I hurried to Mr William Bowditch’s in Otis place. Neither he nor his wife was at home, and I had no small difficulty in obtaining, but did obtain access to the library. I was an hour and a half intensely engaged in searching for the volumes of Schumacher’s Astronomische Nachrichten, containing the accounts of the erection by the Russian Emperor Nicholas of the Astronomical Observatory of Pulkova— I found two of them at last—Volumes 11. and 13.— Numbers 264. August 1834. and 290. 291. 292 18. Novr 1835. I took out the Books and entered my name as the borrower. I next called upon judge Davis, and had a further conversation of half an hour with him. He lent me the companion to Middleton’s celestial Atlas, and also, a Mercator’s map of the Starry heavens comprehending the whole equinoctial and terminated by the polar Circle, published many years ago by William Croswell, a college associate of judge Davis. This is an aid to the study of the constellations of which I had never before heard. At one O’Clock I met by previous agreement with my Son, him and his daughter Louisa Catherine, at Dr Frothingham’s where the Carriage was at that time ordered. Neither the Doctor, nor Mrs Frothingham was at home— But we met there at the time— Benjamin, the driver was punctual to the time with the Carriage, and we came home to Quincy to dine— I came home, burdened more than I ever was before, but with spirits too much dissipated to resume at once the broken thread. A Mr Fuller of Newton with his wife a daughter of William Jackson, returning from an excursion to Plymouth, called to see me for curiosity— Mr Marsh teacher of a school at Milton came with a subscription paper for a contribution to purchase an apparatus for lectures on Natural philosophy: to cost 500 dollars. I went up the hill at Sunset to see Mrs Charles but she was out on a visit to Mrs Lunt— She and Charles afterwards came and spent a short evening here— I could accomplish nothing more than the diary of yesterday though I began with Mary Louisa, the companion to Middleton’s celestial Atlas, comparing the book with the maps; and both with the real spangles in the skies which were never arrayed in brighter splendor than this Evening. I recognized several old acquaintance among the constellations.

Light frost. I wrought with my spade and hoe upon the hill; but found work which can only be done with the plough— The mornings are becoming so cold, and the pressure of my indoor work so excessive that I must henceforth renounce my excursions before sunrise, or limit them to a quarter of an hour. My visitors this day were Lovell Childs; a young man who said he resided at Andover; had some business in this part of the country, and came to see me, from mere curiosity— Next P. Emory Aldrich of Prescott, Massachusetts, William Baker of Newark, Ohio and Daniel D. Atchison of Lexington Kentucky, Students at the Law-school in Cambridge, told me that they came to Quincy to see me and the quarries.— After a short conversation they asked for my autograph— I wrote my name on 3 visiting cards with the date, and asked them, much to their amusement, for their autographs in return; which they gave me, all on one sheet of Letter paper— Then a young man, named George Warren, came from Boston with a recommendatory Letter from William Hayden senior editor of the Atlas, and accompanied by another young man named Turner, to invite and urge me to deliver a Lecture before the mercantile library association, which I was constrained to decline— Mr Lunt was here this evening, wanting to borrow Eliot’s biography for some notice of the death of Leonard Hoar sometime President of Harvard College— The book was at my Son’s up the hill— Mr Lunt found it there, but not what he wanted in it— I strip’d the remainder of wild cherries from the garden seedling, about half a pint, but a full quart had been borrowed while I was at New-Bedford— I picked up a dozen English white oak acorns fallen from the trees; but they all floated. Five or six that I gathered sunk and are plantable— I bought in a wool clad worm with the twig and leaf on which I found him— Charles’s sons John and Charles were brought home from Hingham, and Miss Sampson was taken home to Braintree this afternoon. I read in Schumacher’s Astronomische Nachrichten N. 264. August 1834. the first notice of the Pulkova observatory; and made some further progress in reading Bailly’s history—but not half a page in writing my own address; though I wrote myself more than once asleep.— Charles and his wife were here in the evening. I read with Mary Louisa two Sections of the Companion to Middleton’s celestial Atlas—comparing them with the maps and with the stars in the sky— The Mercator’s map of Croswell is not of much use— I was compelled by mere heaviness of spirit to retire to bed immediately after ten.
